>>18822620
>source: my ass
An alcoholic in the strictest terms is somebody who has an impulsive addiction to alcohol. Usually due to the genetic component which is often comorbid with OCD, ADHD, autism and similar such illnesses. These are people who are likely to become addicted to many things such as substance abuse (including alcohol), food, hoarding, etc. Then there are people who struggle to give up drinking due to the significance it plays in their lives, perhaps it's a centerpiece of their social lives or perhaps they use it to relieve themselves after a stressful job, and if these lifestyle factors were removed, their need for alcohol would be gone. I wouldn't call these people alcoholics in the traditional sense, so borderline alcoholic seems like a fair term to me.

>>18813702
>having to pay your interns
This is baffling to me. The economics are just very strange. For example, many young people looking to further their academic careers but failed to get into a paid PhD program would be willing, if able, to do research unpaid, or even pay for another year of education in the interim before applying again. And yet those hyper-competitive PhD programs still pay salaries (in some form) to their students. However, less-competitive programs do not seem to try to compete with other programs for better students by offering higher salaries, as would be expected in a competitive marketplace, even if they receive a windfall of funding. Part of it's a very intense social psychology for sure -- money is not really supposed to be a motivator -- but at the same time you obviously don't want to shut out, or force extra work upon, those who can't simply live on a parental stipend.

This world of top-tier restaurant internships, and many other classy internships, in theory seems like it should work with at least a somewhat similar mindset -- at least at a certain point the interns should be intrinsically qualified and valuable enough to be paid and competed over, else why have interns in the first place?

It kind of reminds me of that famous 19th-century economist's prediction that the most menial worker's wages would always fall to the bare minimum needed to sustain life. Obviously it's not true in an actual labor market, but doesn't it seem to be even worse in the internship market?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18819923
>an entire means to get work experience
It's called getting an education, showing competence in your school performance, and getting an entry-level job (with entry salary and prestige of the company often, but not always commensurate to said school performance).

Unpaid internships encourage a reduction in the number, quality, and pay inentry level positions, and the ubiquity of them in certain fields also makes the educational quality of the internships vary heavily -- and due to the very nature of internships being outside a school, this quality may have zero oversight.

To expand: it is the norm in industry X (civil engineering or culinary arts, say) to have unpaid internships during and/or shortly after graduation. The number of such students seeking internships is so high that companies with even barely a moderate size or prestige attached have zero trouble consistently having many more qualified candidates applying for internships than they could accept even if they wanted. Many long-lived well-managed firms are high quality and see internships as investing in future hires, and take the education of all interns seriously. However, there are many more mediocre companies than these, and they will often defer interns to low-level staff, who may only devote time to actually educating a handful, while, as is *very stereotypical* relegating the *vast majority* to "coffee duty". They can do this because, again, there are usually many more applicants every year than there are positions. And as a company is not paying interns, which is by nature an investment, there is no incentive for retention, promotion, development, etc.

And this is only looking at part of the problem. Unpaid internships are an inherently inefficient, exploitative, uneconomical system.

>A 6 month internship at Noma or the French Laundry is worth much more than a 4 year degree from CIA.
You obviously didn't see a prior thread from last week where OP linked an article where a former recounted her experience at the world's best restaurant -- the first 3 years were spent simply preparing perfect jelly molds into the shape of beetles. (The article was not primarily about that, but that's what we gravitated to.)

As I detailed, an unpaid internship often isn't worth shit except for a few students, often selected not by their merit but by the luck of the motivation of whichever lowest-level manager is tasked to supervise them. Because the company makes zero financial investment, they have no incentive to oversee the training interns (unless they specifically have an internship-to-career-develop program in place, or their upper management sees education and economic development in general as a long-term investment strategy.).

To take an example from engineering, I know for a fact there are companies who have as an informal policy to make those in their first year of internship just to copies and coffee, such that only those who return for a second year (thus "proving company loyalty" or some shit? What did they do to earn loyalty? I guess you're just proving loyalty to whoever offers you another internship in spite of shitty grades, or whoever promises steady employment in an area you want to live) get to do actual developmental work.

In part this is facilitated by universities competing to get exclusive internship slots for students at big-name companies, but for the most part it wouldn't be possible if at the end of the day the internships were not unpaid.

>>18820505
Hotdog stands in denmark, they are unlike any other hotdogs and it's so difficult to place, I've tried so many dog types and sausages but they're not the same. they also have pickled cucumbers that aren't like regular pickles. there was this remolade yellow sauce that tasted like a really refined big mac sauce. I ate so many of them when I visited and they had stands literally everywhere. It's almost scary how common they are. Stayed a couple nights on the coast in a really rural part. it had like one store for groceries within 20 miles and no other commerce aside from farms. Even in that remote old people place there was still a god damn hot dog trailer that would park outside the grocery every day. I swear you could go hiking in the forest, go off the beaten trail, fall into a ravine and find a hotdog stand at the bottom of it. Only visited once though, so maybe I just had crazy luck.
it's unique because I've never called a hotdog "refreshing" but that's the best way I could describe it.

My parents' coffee situation is weird and, I think, a little bit funny. When I was growing up, they would drink shitty pre-ground Yuban or whatever they'd buy in bulk at Costco. About fifteen years ago, I got a part time at Starbucks, and got them a free bag of a coffee they sell called Casi Cielo, a seasonal Guatemalan coffee they sell, and probably the best whole bean coffee Starbucks carries. They fell in love with it, and asked me to hoard my free bags of coffee and ship it to them, instead of flipping it on eBay as I usually did. I haven't worked at Starbucks in about a decade, but my dad will still go to the local stores and buy up their entire supply whenever it's available, and now it's all they drink and told me they can't really stand the shitty pre-ground supermarket stuff. If they run out of that coffee, they'll switch to tea. When I visited them yesterday, I offered to grind their coffee with my hand grinder, but my mom stopped me because she immediately knew it would make a huge difference to have fresh burr-ground coffee, and she sort of didn't want to know, because she knew the financial rabbit hole coffee snobbery can lead to. They're reluctant to try better beans or better grinders, or better brew methods because they don't want to "have to" start spending more money on their morning coffee.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18823549
A faster, more even extraction is still preferable to a slower uneven one. Its not all that coarse of a grind fwiw, you're just used to looking at massive amounts of fines all over the bed. Better grinders(the anon above is either using a zp6 or kafatek flat) with more narrow particle distributions will let you get away with coarser grinds, but tastier cups because you're more evenly extracting the coffee.
>This shows exactly the “common knowledge” curve I was talking about earlier; if you grind too fine, average extraction yield goes down because your extraction becomes more uneven.
https://coffeeadastra.com/2020/04/02/why-cant-we-grind-coffee-finer-for-pour-over/
>Whenever too many coffee fines get trapped in the pores of a paper filter, the drip rate of a coffee brew can go down drastically. This is not only a problem because the brew becomes much longer: the bigger issue is that whatever water is still able to pass through will do so along smaller, and unchanging paths through the filter. This means that large regions of the coffee bed will potentially stop receiving fresh water, and will remain under extracted, while other regions will receive the bulk of the flow and contribute astringency or other unpleasant flavors caused by over extraction.
https://coffeeadastra.com/2021/03/04/the-four-rules-of-optimal-coffee-percolation/

posts.com: I honestly don't know the answer. It's just not something most Americans would even think of. We eat bread with butter, and buttered toast/bagels/english muffins/biscuits, but the only time we ever really put butter on a sandwich is if it's on the outside and we're toasting it. We usually just use mayo and mustard for most things. It's not like we have inferior bread and butter; it's just not a thing we do. I lived in France for a while and one of the things that honestly surprised me the most was people would actually butter their bread before eating cheese with it. rabbit stew
1 carrot
1 potato
1 turnip
1 cup barley
1 rabbit
1 cup wine
1 herbs
oil
layer veg in bottom of pot
add herb to wine
stuff rabbit with barley
put rabbit on top of veg
add oil and cook slow and cover
when meat is half cooked baste with wine and herbs
salt to taste

>cooking good food for others gives me a sense of purpose
I don't think this can sustain your drive to be a line cook by itself. You won't be like, simmering a nice stew that you lovingly worked on to serve to someone you hope will enjoy it, you'll be putting out dishes literally as fast as possible while adhering to a quality standard. Restaurant dishes are all about timing and order of operations management. Being a good cook isn't even the most fundamental thing because you need to be very fast and organized. There's a pretty limitless skill ceiling too since a lot of the time you can inprove everyone's night by being really cognizant of everything everyone else is doing and heeding off problems before they even happen or noticing other people's mistakes or what they've forgotten. Who you work with makes the biggest difference but if you're no good you'll struggle anywhere because people who are slow or incompetent really do drag everyone else down, but you would be given time to learn by any decent chef.

I like to make anabolic pizza in a pan
>cook chicken in water/pressure cooker so they come out soft not crispy

For the crust use 3 eggs with some corn starch. Just a little is enough (roughly 15 gram). Pour it in a pan, close the lid and flip it after 2-5 minutes and let it bake for another minute. In this time you can slice an onion.

>After the crust is done leave it in the pan and pour/spread 100g of tomato sauce on the crust.
>Chicken should be done by now so crush the chicken in your hand while spreading it on the pizza (I use 1.5 chicken breast. This is a lot but I do it for the protein). This should be relatively easy since you boiled the chicken in water (use the broth for soup). >Spread some cut onion on top of the pizza.
>Sliced/shredded low-fat mozzarella on top to make it all come together
>Heat it all up on the pan with closed lid until the cheese has melted

High protein anabolic pizza you can eat every day which you could make in 15 minutes. Personally I eat only half each day but you could eat the entire thing.

About saturated fat honestly I can't tell you anything. Simply didn't read up enough on that topic. I advise to do your own research. From what I understand it hasn't been made entirely clear yet if it's actually healthy or not.
Cholesterol is divided in good and bad cholesterol. Its important to have plenty of good cholesterol (from whatever source. I eat banana pancakes every morning by blending 2 bananas and 4 eggs then baking the batter. Plenty of good cholesterol and other micros).

Feel free to swap to normal mozzarella instead of low-fat. The entire recipe was a suggestion for how to use chicken in a delicious way and its simply what I do. (I prefer low-fat because I can use more cheese for the same amount of kcal).

Carbonara does not have any cream.
Spaghetti (12 oz)
Eggs (2 + 2yolks) room temperature
Guanciale (3 1/2 oz) pancetta or bacon are fine
Parmigiana Cheese (1/3 cup) grated
Pecorino Romano (1/3 cup) grated
Olive Oil (1 Tbsp.) to render the pork
Salt (1Tbsp.) for the pasta water
Pepper to taste.

>>18824180
>turn the heat off completely since you only need the heat from the pasta.
This is the traditional way, but I've come to realize that proper heat control produces better results. Rapid stirring over low heat, adding extra pasta water if it looks to be getting too dry, yields a far thicker, creamier sauce than the traditional method. When I see traditional carbonara they talk about how creamy it is but to me it looks like a thin glaze on the pasta. My method gives you a more viscous cream-like sauce.

>>18817354
Dressing balances and seasons the vegetables. A big bowl of salad for 4 people only needs at most half a cup of good dressing.

Here is my favorite recipe:
4tbs evoo
1tbs dijon mustard
1tbs of good white wine vinegar
.5-1 clove of minced garlic
S&P

Mix everything except oil. Slowly drizzle evoo into mix until emulsified. Add 2 tsp of water to thin.

Healthy, simple, light dressing that seasons everything and brightens up the greens while not over powering any of the other flavors.

posts.com:
>>18824574

IMO the biggest problem with fast food is that it is very high food-reward, so people eat it even when they are satiated and easily become fat. There are some weird ingredients in most of the stuff they make but it's not THAT bad. You can see for yourself here:

https://www.mcdonalds.com/us/en-us/about-our-food/nutrition-calculator.html

Weirdest thing I saw listed was "DATEM", which is an emulsifier. But it's approved by the EU food authority, and they're a lot stricter than the regulators in the US, so it's probably fine.
I think this trace crap is generally only an issue if you're in poor health and need to go on some kind of restricted diet. If you feel fine and are at a healthy body weight, enjoy your zogchow. Alcohol is probably worse for you.

aw shit i came here to say this! i'll expand briefly--there are several things i like about this cookbook. first off is that everything in it will minimally be good. the recipes are all trustworthy, even if they won't be like your favorite version of something. but with lots of cookbooks you cook something and maybe you don't like it and you're like, does this recipe suck or did i fuck it up? also, and relatedly, the thing i really really like about america's test kitchen recipes is that they explain what their preferred result is. so they'll start a recipe with, 'we like our food xx to be like this and this, and we set out to figure out how to do it.' so you know what THEIR version of good is for a given recipe, which helps you to both decide if you want to make that recipe and, again, makes it possible to see if you you did it right, since they've explained what the results should be like.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First impression tea notes:
2020 Jinggu (200g)
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/936595693/2020-jinggu-200g

Parameters:
12.2g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with short steeps

Taste:
Green bean, a bit green teaish in character (despite having some reddish tinged leaves suggesting some oxidation).
Some of the more traditionally shengy tart apricot and pear flavors.
Moderate bitterness and astringency (I have not had green tea for awhile but again this tea feels like it has a bit of green tea character to it in the way it goes down).
Relatively straightforward but pleasant and easy to drink.

Conclusion:
Seems like a fairly priced daily drinker young sheng, especially if you like a bit of green tea character. Probably a decent cake for newcomers to young sheng as well. At 200g/$20 I don't have any substantial complaints. Though if you dislike green bean taste you may want to stay away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18811155
The internet says it's a yellow tea, I would first try a similar yellow tea. Otherwise, yellow tea is closest to green tea, puerh is probably a poor fit.
https://yunnansourcing.com/products/certified-organic-yunnan-yellow-tea
Note that I haven't specifically tried this, I would prefer one bud one leaf to bud only in this case, and it's cheaper as well. Most people don't really drink yellow tea, I'd order this, potentially this and the bud only tea, and see where you're at. As a bonus, I'd probably throw in some chinese green tea as well.
Mandala tea also aparantly sells some, I also haven't (and probably wouldn't) tried this.
https://www.mandalatea.com/white-teas?category=Yellow+Tea

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18811219
>https://yunnansourcing.com/products/certified-organic-yunnan-yellow-tea
I have actually had that tea a few years back. It is effectively a more lightly oxidized black tea. I recall it having kind of a nice orange marmalade and almond biscotti flavor but also that it could get quite bitter if over brewed (like a lot of black tea).

>>18811219
>I would prefer one bud one leaf to bud only in this case, and it's cheaper as well.
Besides price why? I did not have the pure bud version but I suspect it may be slightly better because the buds will highlight some of that teas lighter more floral elements better over the bitter "maltiness". I do do doubt it is twice as good though so it is not going to be as good of value.
https://yunnansourcing.com/collections/yunnan-sourcing-brand-certified-organic-teas/products/certified-organic-emperors-yellow-yunnan-yellow-tea

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18811297
You can generally get stronger sweeter tea from a bit more stem / leaf. Buds are "lighter" because they don't extract well, you do get more floral notes though. One bud one leaf should push you farther into honey territory.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
matcha ice cream:
2qt half & half
12 egg yolks
2 cup sugar or 1 cup erythritol 1 cup allulose (or xylitol) or 2 cup erythritol if eating within 48 hours
matcha (doesn't matter, the sugar and cream is gonna murder any subtleties of the leaf)
25 dollar walmart churn https://www.walmart.com/ip/Nostalgia-4-Quart-Electric-Ice-Cream-Maker-Blue/749542584
big boxes of salt

1. make matcha with the half & half. it honestly doesn't matter how much you make, i've used just fuck my shit up levels and it was perfectly fine. it just has to dissolve
2. put a metal bowl on the stove and dump everything in it. remember to break yolks. add pinch of salt. turn the heat to maximum and stir it
3. you can do this until either the sugar is fully dissolved or to official guideline which is like 150F to kill salmonella. use infrared thermometer and remember what temperature you turned the heat off at for next time
4. dump ice cream custard into ice cream maker cylinder and put it in the fridge for a few hours
5. make lots of ice sitting in the freezer the day before
6. put cylinder in bucket, put paddle in cylinder, put motor on, dump layer of ice, layer of salt till it's full and plug in
7. churn for about 20-30 min or until it fails to churn. if you used sugar or plain erythritol, it's ready to eat. if you used erythritol with alluose (or xylitol), it needs a day or two in the freezer to get firmer. the bottom is usually ready though.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18819787
Higher fermentation, darker tastes, more mellow, more rounded out, if fermented properly they are ready to drink much sooner, don't benefit much from aging.
Lighter fermentation, more likely to be bitter, retains more of the teas original character, less rounded and smoothed out, the really lightly fermented stuff needs a pretty solid aging period before its ready to drink, but they haven't produced much like that since the early 2000s and further back.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18822295
That doesn't apply to shou puerh, shou was developed in the 70s to mimic the taste of aged sheng. The whole point is that it needs to be drinkable immediately, without aging. It doesn't actually taste like aged sheng, but it certainly doesn't benefit in the same way from aging, although properly stored aged shou can be pretty good. This will not happen in your pumidor. Young sheng was the only puerh that was drunk for most of history, young sheng is still what is drunk today in Puer. Aged puerh was a market that was created to shift the large amounts of stock of puerh that existed primarily in Hong Kong to Taiwan, it spread from there. Similarly to shou, however, if you have a bing or batch of maocha that doesn't taste very good, it's bad tea. Aging will not fix it, because the tea is simply bad. If you age good tea, the flavor will transform as the years pass, and if you store it properly, it can improve significantly. You cannot do this with bad tea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18822431
"designed for aging" just means that the tea isn't processed as green as people might be used to. The tea should still taste good young. Parts of the world, primarily Taiwan, HK, Guangdong, don't really drink young sheng. That doesn't mean that young sheng is undrinkable, or that it's acceptable for it to have any of the flaws you'd usually assosciate with bad tea. Flat taste, high bitterness, weak liquor, or any obvious defects like it being murky from oversteaming, toasted or burnt, etc. The tea commonly drunk on whatever your preferred tea mountain is, Jingmai, Yiwu, whatever, could also be aged as is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18825706
Roiboos all comes from one farming collective in africa. So basically no matter where you buy it from its comming from the same farms and blended in the same warehouse for export. Freshness will make the biggest difference in quality. I also think it does better with short steeping times. 60-90 seconds. Mountain rose herbs should have straight unflavored roiboos and its cousin Honeybush which i think is better personally, it's extremely sweet but again keep brew times short for best results.
For mate you want to buy the proper south American brands, you can find them on places like amazon.
Some super premium brands are mate & co and Anna Park. More reasonably priced brands look for La Merced, for more affordable brands rosamonte especial and cruz de malta.
There is a lot of variety with taste and flavors between brands, some are sweeter, some more bitter, some smoked. You need to try some and figure out what you like if you want to get into it.

4 cups whole wheat flour
Pint of water
Yeast pack
Tablespoon honey
Teaspoon salt

Proofed yeast with honey in the warmed water, then mixed with the flour and salt (which I had sifted together). Kneaded it until it was plump and well incorporated
Let rise for an hour covered by a hot damp towel, rewarmed towel and placed dough in a bread tin and let it rise for another hour. Baked for 15 minutes at gas mark 7 (425F), then for another 40 minutes at gas mark 4 (350F).

Ok, what are you doing, baking it? Putting it into soup? etc

If baking, just coat the outside with oil and season, and stuff the cavity with chopped onion, garlic, and citrus, and bake at 400 to 425 until the skin is crispy, basting every 20 min or so with chicken broth or better yet the juices running off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18824758
I cook whole chickens often. By far my favorite method is spatchcocking and roasting in a cast iron or large roasting pan for a large chicken. You cut out the backbone and flatten the bird before roasting. Here's a chef john video showing the technique https://youtu.be/37UB_7q9c7M
That recipe is good, I've made it a few times. But if you want something simpler and more traditional you can't go wrong with a butter and herb compound butter. Mix a stick of butter with minced garlic, salt, pepper, thyme, rosemary, and lemon zest. Rub half under the chicken skin and the rest all over the exterior before roasting.
Also, don't roast the chicken in a very shallow pan and definitely don't use a rimless sheet pan. A lot of fat and juices will render out and you don't want them leaking.
I typically throw in a bunch of potatoes and carrots to fill the void space in my roasting pan. You don't want it too crowded, but they'll taste great having been cooked in chicken fat for an hour.
When it's done, remove the bird and rest it a few minutes. Make a gravy from the drippings using a roux or corn starch slurry to thicken.
No idea about the bone powder.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I like to cook chicken in a cast iron skillet over a bed of seasoned/oiled quartered potatoes, quartered sweet onion, carrots, celery, and thyme sprigs. As far as process: cut the bag over the sink, check the cavity for neck and organs (remove), pat the whole thing down with paper towels to dry the skin, season skin and inside cavity, fill cavity with aromatics, rub skin with oil. I get good results starting with high heat, 425 F, for the first 15-20 minutes depending on bird size to crisp the skin, then drop down to 375 for 45-55 minutes or until temp hits if I have a thermometer in the thigh. Without a thermometer, cut into the thigh and the juice should be clear. Not fancy, but I hope this helped.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
make sure to season the chicken inside and out, you could also make a compound butter and spread it between the skin and meat. If it's a bigger chicken then tie the legs and wings together (truss) this will prevent a lot of hot air to circulate around the chicken and prevent the wings and legs from burning. Roast a lightly oiled pan at 350f or 175-176c for about an hour for a 3lb chicken. After about 45 min, you can stick a thermometer in there to gauge how much time is left.
STEPS:
Pre heat oven to 350
Take the chicken out of the plastic, pat dry with paper towels, season liberally in and out, or use a compound butter.
Truss the legs and wings.
Lightly oil roasting pan
Roast
Maybe add halved russet potatoes to the pan
to cut the breast slice on either side of the spine
for legs cut the joint between the legs and thighs
for most cuts its just a matter of cutting it at the joint.

For the bones, you should boil them to remove the excess meat and soften them. Then roast them for about 30 min at 350 to sterilize them. from there you can grind them up and thats how you make bone meal. Calcium powder can also be made eggshells.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My best friend of 20 years died of esophageal cancer about four years ago, leaving behind a wife and three daughters. It's a tough place to be as most folks don't survive it.

What you want is something high in fat, carbs and protein. Weight gain shakes are pretty reliable. If he doesn't like sweet then well blended legume dishes like pea soup, real home-made baked beans or cassoulet are the way to go.
If he can cope with sweet, things like pavlova and peanut butter brownies are ideal.

Good luck anon. It's shit watching someone you consider to be a brother wither and die while you can do nothing to help. My heart goes out to you and I pray your friend has a better outcome than mine.

Try to be understanding, because nobody gave me any understanding at all. And I know its way worse with cancer. Its not just as simple as forcing yourself to eat.

>>18823232
Had one of these for my 40th birthday. I live in a pretty small city so there weren't ever any fancy pizza places besides the usual chains until recently.
Went to the fanciest place in town where they don't have dollar signs on their menu that's how you know you're rubbing shoulders with the upper crust of society.
Paid almost 30 dollars for it but it was pretty big much larger than those small ones you see in europe. I was worried I would be disappointed being used to normal topping laden american style pizza but it was actually a real nice change of pace. The sauce had more flavor than I could ever have imagined pizza sauce could have and it all just worked together to make a delicious combination.
My only complaint is that the cheese doesn't stay melty for long, by the time I was on my second slice it had already sort of hardened up and wasn't nearly as good as that first slice.
I would definitely order it again if I had the chance. Can't say if it it's my favorite pizza but easily in the top 5.

>>18817346
You can put this to a test actually! Get a timer or stopwatch, a measuring cup and turn on your faucet for 15 seconds. Multiply the amount of water you've collected and you have your faucets output by mintute. Your dishwasher has a user manual that will tell you how many gallons or liters it uses per cycle, but if you don't trust this you can monitor your water meter and see for yourself! If it was manufactured after 2010, it likely uses somewhere between 2 and 4 gallons per cycle.

Now that you've established how much water you use per minute from your faucet, time yourself washing your dishes. With some simple math, you'll see if your feeling about water and energy use is correct or not (it won't be, by the way).

If I have lots of dishes I fill the both sides of the sink, one for washing the other for rinsing. Or I'll use a tub if I have a single sink. My scrubbing takes ~4 secs per plate. Which is ~3-5 scrubs. So thats 12 secs per day x 365 = 73 minute per year.

Pic related cost $300 + dish washer takes anywhere from 2-3 hours per cycle in normal mode. posts.com:
So I recently made the switch from canned beans to dried beans.
Turns out, dried beans give you A LOT of beans, which is great because beans are good.
Problem is, I don't think I'm cooking them quite right. When fully cooked, the beans have a very beany taste to them. I'm a guy that works with low seasoning, but even with a bunch of salt on there it feels like eating grass.
I was wondering if anyone had tips of things to add to flavor the beans during the cooking process. I was thinking beef stock, maybe extra ramen stock that piles up, garlic salt... okay I don't have a lot of ideas so far.
Also, when spicing things up, would it be best to add during the overnight soak, during the long cook, or during the short cook (usually I make a big batch so I reheat the post-cooked beans again, I call this the short cook).
I like to use Navy beans and Great Northern beans btw

>>18820452
>bunch of salt
I add salt when soaking and cooking, but I never add salt when I eat it.
Add chili powder/paprika and aspartame to your beans.

I also always eat beans with tomato products, usually ice tomatos, tomato puree, tomatoe paste, and the like.
I also enjoy them with carrots or mushrooms.
Aspartame is the ultimate flavor enhancer.
Other spices to add
onion powder,
garlic powder
black pepper
pepper flakes
italian seasoning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18820452
Bay leaves.

A technique that most Brazilians use is to simply par-cook the beans in lightly salted water, freeze it in smaller portions, then when we want to eat the beans, we make a base of sautéed onions, garlic, whatever you want, and allow the beans to simmer in that for a few minutes before serving. That way, you can always customize your beans according to what you want to eat, so I don't recommend cooking the beans in any kind of stock, because it will limite your use of them.

posts.com: I'm currently buried in sleeping /k/itties, but I made lentils last night. Cut four rashers of thick cut bacon into bite sized pieces, browned them in the pot to retain delicious fat, removed from heat, added seasonings (Bay leaves, celery seed, copious thyme, a little fresh black pepper, a little crushed red pepper, just a touch of sea salt) and aromatics, specifically some yellow onion and half a dozen whole cloves of garlic. Then went the lentils themselves, then the water, and then it was back onto the stove to simmer for about an hour or so. I'm pretty pleased with the results, and my brother seemed to like it well enough.

>>18823085
Here's some tips on getting good oven spring: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_sJ0HhqN6UM
Instead of messing with steaming in the oven I just:

1. Put an empty dutch oven into an oven and set the temp to 500F. Wait until the pot is thoroughly preheated. (How long? I'm not exactly sure. 10+ min after the oven reaches 500F.)
2. Put your dough onto a lightly-dusted parchment sheet.
3. Score the bread.
4. Take the dutch oven out, place the bread inside, put the lid on, place in the oven, and turn the oven off. Wait 20 min.
5. Turn the oven on to 425F convection or 450F regular. Remove the lid. Cook for 10 min.
6. Remove dutch oven, remove bread from pot with parchment and place in oven. Cook 5 min.
7. Remove parchment from oven. Rotate loaf. Cook 5 min.
8. Keep rotating the loaf and waiting 5 min until the desired brownness is reached. Inside is done when it reaches 200F.

>>18818126
>how do i zazz up my mac and cheese?
Well, Annies always tastes like cardboard box it was shipped in, so start with not buying it ever again. I have found the store brands are always better than than that crap. For instance, Publix brand is better than Kraft and doesn't have the MSG-ish additves.

But, if you really want to upgrade your craft without a bechamel step, then go for the back of the box recipe with Barilla. Cook your less flimsy nice pasta noodles in the milk itself, with a diced onion. Shred in your real aged cheddar, letting the pasta sauce be thickening with the natural starch in the milk cooking liquid. A little pinch of cayenne can sharpen up the cheese funk, or pinch of white pepper or mustard powder, alternately.
Top your quick mac n cheese with crisply toasted seasoned fresh breadcrumbs or panko. I like a bit of parm in crumbs. Their crunch adds some texture.

posts.com: The reason people from Napoli put raisins in meatballs is because someone misread uova (eggs, a normal meatball ingredient) and thought it was uva (grapes, not a normal meatball ingredient). Any sane person would reread it, but someone was so stupid that they were like: oh shit- I guess these meatballs contain grapes, and did it anyway like a madman. so yeah, that's how that terrible recipe was created. A recipe that the mere description of is enough for anyone who has a functioning tongue to visibly recoil and exclaim that a mistake had been made.

I am a long-time stoner and have tried just about every method of consumption rich and poor. I'll go into a little more detail but the TL;DR is that edibles will always be about masking the cannabis not enhancing a dish

DO NOT use high quality herb for edibles. It is an absolute waste and no matter how hard you work they will taste like shit and be wildly different in dosage throughout. If you are going to use a vaporizer you can use the ABV to make some oil or butter later as a way to squeeze every bit of the THC out but don't expect it to taste good - mask it with heavy amounts of chocolate or peanut butter and strain that fucker multiple times through cheesecloth.

The oil you'll be getting is decarbed already and can be used as/for edibles which is much easier than making cannabutter and makes it easier to hide the taste as well.

Personally I'm not a huge fan of edible highs, but for those that do I recommend RSO over going to the trouble of trying to make something tasty.

>>18823948
>I know its quite different, by not being food at all but it feels strange to not use high quality ingredients.
The main difference is that the cannabis flower isn't what you're cooking with (and cooking with it would be awful) and the raw flower can't be ingested to get high. Any recipe for edibles begins with processing and refining the cannabis into a different product altogether.
The quality of ingredients going into any kind of refinement process is usually besides the point, as the process itself is meant to remove everything you don't want.

tl;dr you wouldn't make sausage out of wagyu

>>18813328
Take a basic lean bread recipe. 5/3 flour to water. For 20oz of flour, use 2tsp salt, 1/2tsp yeast, and 1oz olive oil(don't buy it at the grocery store, grocery store oil is adulterated and rancid, regardless of what the bottle says).

Literally just mix this all together into a dough ball, then need it until the dough is smooth and you can stretch part of it thin enough light passes through.

Then portion it into however many pizzas you are making, and ball it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oZxNbL5XB7w

Then shove each dough ball in an oiled, sealed container that's big enough to allow it to expand, then shove those containers in the fridge for 48 hours.

Come back, let them warm up enough to work with, and then stretch them out. The dough should be quite thin, 1/3 an inch, with a bit more on the edges.

kneading high hydration dough by hand is a waste of time. it will form a strong gluten network by itself over a period of several hours (google autolysis). all you had to do was wait - you could have simply tossed it in the refrigerator overnight - but your impatience and inexperience got the best of you. posts.name: Anonymous

>>18813932
5 minutes by hand is approximately nothing. I knead my pasta dough for around 10 minutes and pasta dough builds gluten very quickly. for a pizza dough you're looking at 30-60 minutes of hand kneading depending on exactly how wet your dough is, what type of flour you are using, and what additions you're using.
>>18813940
yeah he used a mixer with a dough hook. if you don't have a machine to do the kneading then you're better off just letting the gluten build up naturally through autolysis. wet dough responds very slowly to kneading, you could easily spend an hour by hand to get the level of gluten development he got in just a few minutes on the machine, or you could just give it a few folds every hour for a few hours and get the same result with a lot less work.

Why would you want it to rise before putting it in the freezer like it's the oven? There's absolutely no point to that. It's better to freeze an unrisen dough. When you freeze anything you should have it sealed in an airtight bag and press out any air that you can.

posts.com:
I've had good luck with my pizza's recently. I use this recipe...

3 cups of flour (2 white 1 wheat or all white)
3 tsp yeast (standard red star stuff you can get in most grocery stores.
Optional: a tbsp or two of sugar
1-2 cups of HOT HOT, but not boiling, water

First: You'll need a baking stone in the oven.

Methodology, flour and yeast in bowl, mix / fluff (you could also just sift). Add one cup of water mix throughout with your hand until fully absorbed. Start adding small amounts of water and repeat the mixing until you get large clumps that are not sticky to the touch. Knead until all flour in incorporated and the dough is slightly sticky. Leave it alone for 20 minutes. Come back and turn dough into ball (the one you see all the pro chefs do on youtube). Then cover in a dusting of flour and bag the bowl or put a lid on it.

Now you wait at least one hour, but preferably an afternoon or so before rolling it out and putting toppings on it.

To cook it; turn the oven on 30-60 minutes before the pizza goes in and turn it on high. Like 500 F. Top pizza, put in for 5 minutes, turn and check on cheese / crust, cook for another 4-5 minutes and take out.

>teach me how to make a good pizza dough
For an 18" crust :
1 US cup of water
Yeast (1 tbsp or so)
Olive oil (1/4 cup or less)
Salt (1 tbsp or less)
Flour

Mix all this together. You'll need enough flour to get the dough just sticky, but not to much. The other measurements are up to taste, really. I always eyeball it.
Kneed - you should have learned this from your mother. Or at school. Watch a YT if you dunno how.
Cover with olive oil, let it rest. A long slow rest at low temp (cook room for 6 hours) will give you a better dough the a short fast rest a higher temp.

Then you will grease your pan and spread out the dough. Or flour a counter top and roll out your dough.

If you want to get fancy, make a pre-ferment : 1 cup flour, 1 cup water, yeast. You mix all this up the night before and let the yeast have fun over night. Add in the oil, salt and rest of the flour the next morning and let it rise all day.

A wetter (aka stickier) dough will make a better crust but will be harder to kneed if you are doing it by hand.

everybody kneads the shit out of their dough but they're doing it wrong so they're just adding extra work for shittier dough

Just mix the ingredients until combined then let sit for 10-15 min and come back and do a few cross folds every 10-15 min afterward for 4-6 time and even the stickiest dough's will be manageable and have much better
>https://youtu.be/6JQm2n4aVZctexture/crumb

picrel is my pizza dough recipe + i oil the bowl that its proofing in so it doesn't stick and i can do the cross folds

#1.mix salt into flour
#2.make dent in flour and add yeast and water, let sit a few min to hydrate yeast
#3.stir until it starts to come together then add oil
#4 stir until combined and the flour is pulling off the sides
#5. Let it rest 15min (covered)
#6. cross fold a few times every 15min for 5 to 7 times (also add some oil to the bowl at this point)
#let it proof on the counter (covered) for 4 up to 12 hours (you'll need a very large bowl with a lid that snaps on tightly )

>>18818753
Shake your pizza as you build it.
Put ample corn meal or wheat on the peel, put your crust on it
Shake it so it slides freely
Put your sauce on
Shake it so it slides freely
Put toppings on, shake it so it slides freely

If at any point it doesnt slide freely, lift up the crust and use a paper towel under it to remove moisture, and then shake it some more.

It should slide like its on ice skates while sitting on your pizza peel.
Make sure you take the sliding into account when topping the pizza, because its going to get launched. Less cheese and toppings you drop the better

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Use King Arthur All Purpose or Bread Flour. It kicks the shit out of the other stuff at the grocery store. Get a kitchen scale so you can measure it by weight and control the hydration. 58-62% is what you want. Get a stone or a steel and preheat it for at least 45 minutes. You don't need a mixer. Just stir it together and let it rest for an hour and then do some light kneading to make it smooth. Put it in an oiled container in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours.

Use a dough calculator and make the balls by Thickness Factor. .1 TF is fairly thick, like a chain pizza. .065 is where it is pretty thin.

https://pizzadoughcalculator.vercel.app/calculator

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18822677
>Use King Arthur ... Bread Flour.
>measure it by weight and control the hydration.
>58-62% is what you want.
I agree with this advice, OP. start with these.

I also want to add my personal recommendation for a perforated pizza pan. I much prefer it to a stone (I haven't used a steel). I literally threw out my stone when we moved and just use a cheap perforated pan. I don't need to preheat it and the results are preferable to me. I bake at 550F, so I don't need to have my oven that hot for an extra 45 minutes initially plus extra time between pizzas to recharge the stone/steel. I've used several kinds and some are better than others: a dark coating, with more larger holes is preferable like in picrel.

So I've had people rant and rave at me for ages about how amazing rice cookers are
Me, I'm just a regular idiot who cooks rice on a stovetop. The directions say, equal parts water, cook 15 minutes, don't take the lid off. So that's what I do and the rice is cooked and perfect in 15 minutes.

Then I got a rice cooker for christmas, I'd always wanted one, I was pretty excited.

And you know what? It's fucking crap. It cooks rice fine but what takes me 15 minutes on a stovetop takes 50!!! minutes in a rice cooker. The rice that comes out is otherwise identical, and the rice cooker takes like 3 minutes longer to clean than my pot does. because it's got more parts. I've clearly missed something here because this is not easier and more convenient for rice cooking, it takes the exact same amount of effort as cooking on stovetop but 4x longer to cook and a little more effort to clean.

So why the hell do people buy these things instead of just cooking on the stove? Is it really so fucking hard to just not lift the lid to stir the rice for 99% of the population or something???

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813813
It depends on the type of rice down to the specific cultivar really, but great rice is when you coax the most flavor and desirable texture out of your rice.

If you cook rice exactly the same every time you are not good at cooking rice. As rice ages, and the variance from bag to bag it needs adjustment in the cooking process, mainly more or less water.

If you aren't critically assessing the rice you mads, and thinking of how you can try to improve it the majority of the time you aren't even on the path of achieving great rice. You're merely using it as an easy filler food.

Rice is easy to cook, difficult to perfect.

Rice cookers are convenient because they hold the rice at a warm temperature after they are done and you literally can't fuck it up unless you mismeasure. It's one task that no longer requires your attention at all(whereas stovetop rice requires you to at least be minimally aware and can be burnt). Many people are very anxious in the kitchen, so they overvalue the idiot-proof nature of the rice cooker.

That being said, if you eat rice every day they are great. A good rice cooker can not only cook perfect rice without effort, it can also hot hold it all day, and reheat leftover rice perfectly.

Personally, I mostly eat Basmati rice at home, so I just boil it like pasta if I want plain rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813853
>>18814657
No, the previous anon is 100% correct. I cook over 90 litres of sushi rice a week and the amount of water required to get the correct consistency varies from an even 1/1 ratio to 1/1.25 depending on the crop. As we get later in the season it gets drier and drier. Me and the sushi chef taste every single batch. It needs to have a specific firmness, and the release of starch also needs to be controlled so it's slightly sticky, meaning that I also vary the amount of rice conditioner and the time I spend rinsing it. The quality of the rice also varies along what proportion of the rice grains are broken; with higher proportions from lower quality crops(like the most recent Calrose crop) requiring additional rinsing as the broken grains release more starch,

>>18820882
Here you go:

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.


I THINK that the uneven flame/heat creates "heat turbulence" along with the specific shape of the pot. I haven't actually researched it all that much, so if anyone knows any better chime in please.

>If you ask a Japanese person what is Italian food, they think of tomato sauce, pasta and cheese. If you ask an Italian what is American food, they'll think of barbecue and burgers. If you ask an Argentinian about Japanese food, they'll think of sushi.

This might be true, but these cultures are used t eating good quality produce; that is the first thing mentioned in that post. Americans on average only eat incredibly low quality vegetables and protein since they were kids; they haven't built an expectation for what good ingredients taste like. The chlorinated chicken, the refrigerated eggs, the GMO vegetables, they all compromise flavor for something else.

It's the reason why Americans interested in gastronomy are genuinely surprised when they do travel abroad and eat simple food and it tastes great. In these other cultures, when we make a simple dish we expect it to be tasty like our good memories of it, and we get pissed of when the courgette, carrot, tomato, sea bream, shrimp, turkey leg, etc is of poor quality. For americans, that's the norm. That's why Americans regularly cite eating some extremely simple yet tasty dish X at country Y as a life changing experience. American society sacrificed love and respect for food as a cultural phenomenon in lieu of abundance and excess availability. Obviously a few americans are against that and try to go down the other path, but I imagine it's almost impossible to become accustomed to something that just isn't as easily available (quality ingredients).

posts.com:
Looking for some cheap, repeatable lunch and dinner ideas.

I have these 'phases' where I eat basically the same thing for lunch and dinner for several months at a time and it's time to find a new thing.

So far I've went through:
- Chicken fried rice (Not very filling, oil smell afterwards)
- Spaghetti with sausage slices, storebought sauces (Not very filling, can change up sauces tho)
- Basic deli sandwich (Cheap but boring, not very filling so I usually eat canned soup with it)
- Burrito with chicken, homemade pico, guac, fake salsa (By far the most work, but decently filling)
- Grilled chicken, veg and rice (Very cheap, but boring after a while)

Preferably something that doesn't require frying with oil because it's hard to ventilate.
Something that doesn't require any cheese, or very little cheese.
<30 min cooking time, would love a one pot solution.

Any ideas would be useful, thanks friends.
pic unrelated

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18824669
Most things worth eating that can be cooked in one pot/pan/sheet in under 30 mins require frying in oil to some extent.

some old favorites of mine;
roasted chickpea broccoli burritos. switch up the veggies, beans, spices, and use other rice/grain fillings and these will keep you busy for years. prep can be under 10 minutes start to finish including cleanup, cooktime usually more like an hour but you can make huge batches and eat them for days.

Mujadara. Make sure to use black caviar lentils or this can suck. I like to add more veggies and other ingredients for more of a pilaf or casserole but if you get the recipe dialed you can eat this for months or years at a time.

>>18824669
>One pot/pan and under 30 min
Do you consider unattended time? And what are your thoughts on batch prepping?

That being said, assuming a strict interpretation.
>Frittata
Pick whatever fillings you fancy, cook them in a pan, pour a mixture of egg and milk over top once the filling is cooked, stir, then throw in a 350 oven for 10-20 min.

>Pot Pie
Cook some diced meat and frozen vegetables in an oven-safe frying pan with oil or butter. Once cooked, toss in some flour and coat everything. When the flour has dissolved, add chicken stock and stir over low heat for 8-10 minutes until a thick sauce has developed. Thin it with some milk, roll some puff pastry over the top of the pan so it covers all the filling(poke some vent holes in it), then put it in a 400 degree oven until the pastry is cooked and brown. If you are quick you can get it out in 30 minutes, but it'll take a little longer the first time probably.

>Meatloaf
Instead of making a big one just make several small ones to significantly lower the cook time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Being a picky eater isn't about the amount of foods you dislike. It's about the way in which you dislike them. Every adult with anything resembling a developed palate is going to have preferences, but having preferences doesn't make you a picky eater. It only takes a single food/ingredient to make someone a picky eater, and you know they're a picky eater because they absolutely will not give that ingredient a chance no matter what it's in or how it's prepared. And usually it's a very common ingredient (onions, tomatoes, pickles, olives, seafood of any kind, celery, licorice/anise, mushrooms, etc.). These people could go to one of the best restaurants around, or just have someone they trust cook a meal for them, but if they see that there's olives or tomatoes involved they will obstinately refuse to even give it a chance, and if you force them to try one bite they will pretend like they're going to vomit because they have some deep set psychological issues stemming from one bad experience in their childhood and are unwilling to grow up. Often times this is the result of poverty and ignorance; I honestly can't think of a single food that I didn't enjoy at first but would never try again. There were a bunch of foods I didn't like as a kid, but then I had them prepared in a different way and realized they're some of my favorite things (salmon, goat cheese, zucchini come to mind). But a picky eater will insist that (e.g.) olives are yucky and there's no possible situation in which anyone could like them but everyone else is pretending.

>>18821875
If you're using something like a cast iron on electric, it can hold those insanely high heats long enough to get a sear on anything. The reason they prefer gas is because of the total BTU is higher, so when you're doing orders you can sear off an order a lot quicker because it's always going to be at least as hot as it needs to be.

Electric will get hot enough if you give it enough time, and get hotter than gas but if you overwhelm the amount of heat stored in the pan, electric won't heat it up again fast enough.

I think a nice pan with a copper core like All-Clad on an electric coil is the easiest way to cook when you have to control temperature precisely. If you really need insane temps than use an ash oven.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who has used all 3:
Electric is the worst. Not in terms of being to make great food - it does fine - but in terms of everything else. Heat doesn't resize itself. Glasstop gets uneven with stains with use that makes surface contact worse overtime. Fire that goes on and off (non constant).
Gas is almost as bad. Cleaning alone is a bitch. You get a constant fire and you get to use round bottom pans (woks) but if anything breaks it's a pain in the ass.
Induction is the best. easy to clean, temperature doesn't fluctuate as much as electric, and the only flaw is that you still need a flat bottom pan. Unless you're one of the 3 guys who somehow found the high thermal conductivity of completely dry copper pans To be absolutely essential/need woks you can scratch and swivel against a gas bracket or you'll die, induction really feels like the future.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18821972
>Fire that goes on and off
that is a malfunction and not intended.
reason is the thermostat puts it into overheat shutdown, which should not happen before ~370°C on the pan bottom.
Either a too reflective pan or the thermostat is set wrong.
one can be fixed by sanding the bottom dull (or a not reflective pan), the other can be adjusted on the thermostat

Thai curry flavorings really need the fatty coconut base to temper the heat and carry flavor properly. There are variations commonly referred to as "jungle curry" or "forest curry" which exclude coconut because they originate from areas where coconuts were not traditionally available; but these dishes suck ass. Panang incorporates peanuts, possibly lessening the reliance on coconut, but recipes will vary. Yellow curries typically contain familiar Indian/British spice mixes, though relatively heavy use of coriander can cause a soapy taste.

I think he's cool.

Since this is our first /ssg/ lets start off with a little history.

It has been estimated that as much as two-thirds of deceased soldiers in the US Civile War were killed not by bullets but by disease, with the most prevalent of those diseases being the intestinal illnesses diarrhea and dysentery. It was not clear, based on the established medical knowledge, exactly what caused these illnesses to flourish in military camps, but one physician by the name of James H. Salisbury suspected diet was the greatest culprit, and came up with his own solution.

He believed vegetables and starchy foods produced poisonous substances in the digestive system which were responsible for heart disease, tumors, mental illness and tuberculosis. He believed that human dentition demonstrated that humans were meant to eat meat, and sought to limit vegetables, fruit, starches, and fats to one-third of the diet.

The Salisbury steak, his means of achieving this goal, is ground beef flavored with onion and seasoning and then deep-fried or boiled and covered with gravy or brown sauce. It was introduced in 1888. Salisbury saw beef as an excellent defense against many different physical problems. He suggested that Salisbury steak should be eaten three times a day, with much hot water to cleanse the digestive system. He was an early American proponent of a low-carbohydrate diet for weight loss, and he promoted his diet for that purpose. His diet became known as the "Salisbury diet".

Four Loko is illegal because it contains both alcohol and caffeine, which when combined can lead to a state of wide-awake drunk, where a person may feel alert and able to drive or make other poor decisions while still under the influence of alcohol. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) banned Four Loko in 2010, citing safety concerns associated with the combination of caffeine and alcohol.

On the other hand, Irish coffee is legal because it contains only alcohol and caffeine from coffee, and not in a combination that would create a dangerous state. The amount of caffeine in Irish coffee is generally lower than the amount found in energy drinks and it is not mixed with other stimulants.
Additionally, Irish coffee is typically consumed in a more controlled setting, such as a bar or restaurant, where a person is less likely to engage in risky behavior, while energy drinks like Four Loko are often consumed in a party or social setting where excessive drinking is more likely to occur.

posts.com:
>>18823985
>Lustau sherry
Isn't that not even legally sherry in Europe? Like in the U.S. I think that's something like $12 a bottle, which for most people (not all) makes it just about drinkable, briefly, before you use it for cooking. The whiskeys are just all $25--35 range depending on where you shop, and are usually recommended as "introductory" or beginner affordable bottles. Also, there are several bartending guides which note that the required markup for using top-shelf liquors in cocktails is only a few cents per drink (coming to maybe a half to a dollar total altogether), which is a fixed cost where most of the markup for the cocktail is for labor, maintenance, and paying to keep the doors open -- so when you do the microeconomics correctly the customer should only pay that 50 cents extra per drink if you use top-shelf liquor, regardless of how cheap or expensive your bar is in general. In theory that's a price every customer would be happy to pay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18823985
>>18824096
It's not that most of those liquors are *bad* for a consumer -- Banhez and Gran Centenario are considered very good bargain choices. Aside from the economics above, it's just that, to choose those liquors, the bar manager presumably would have had to see other liquors, and thus would know that these are some of the cheapest liquors out there (and would likely have had to do research to know that these are the cheapest ones that are actually drinkable, aside from the sherry). So then my biggest question is, **why advertise the brand names???** Hell, bars that use exclusively top-shelf liquors don't note the brand names, for many reasons.

There's three that from my just-started-learning cocktail knowledge look possibly serviceable:
>Six Seeds
Looks like it started with a French 75, and then just went nuts with the juice, then added a bunch of spice when they could no longer taste the alcohol?
>The Modern Lover
I was gonna say this looked like a Grand/Orange Manhattan, but then I looked up Kronan, which is a rum/arrack liqueur described as toffee-like. Maybe it could work.
>Seven Door Slam
It might be based on a Sazerac if the Aperol is being used like bitters?
>Mezcal Safecracker
I've never made or had a good Negroni, so I don't know how subtle they're supposed to be. Maybe this could work?
>Cosmotropolis
It's literally just spiked fruit punch.

I've been working on mixing drinks every other day for weeks now and I've made a proper classic drink balance correctly exactly once. Purely by luck, too, apparently, because I haven't been able to recreate it. I don't know when if ever I'll be able to make up *good* cocktails (of the *subtle* kind, not just desserts). If they don't have experienced bartenders just dig up hundred-year-old Central European books and steal weird recipes from there.

>>18824340
I'm working on drinks that involve enhancing/evaluating a single spirit and balancing seasonings like bitters, vermouth, etc.: Martinis, Manhattan, Old Fashioned. I'm not making Negronis and variations yet because I haven't settled on the Campari/knockoff I want to buy yet. I'll get a 50mL soon to see what I should expect it to taste like at least.

The noob mistake I found out I was making earlier was using too old and too much citrus peel for the twists. They get more bitter with age, and given how big the twist was relative to how small the cocktails I'm making are, I think I'm just getting way too much bitterness from the peels. Also, after having this bitterness, not washing the glass instead of just rinsing is problematic. The one perfect Old Fashioned I made was with a cheap (but really good) blanco tequila and Peychauds in a fresh glass when I forgot to add another twist of my old citrus.

Basically the recipe for variants is the same for every spirit. It only really doesn't make sense for gin (and distilled botanical spirits) (unless perhaps aged, or old tom, or genever) and vodka and infusions.

>>18825085
Aperol, which can often adequately substitute Campari, also has its own specified recipes and as I don't have a lot of space for bottles, I'd rather get something versatile that does as much legwork as possible. Also I enjoy novelty a little bit.

For vermouth it's M&R red and Dolin dry, as is usually recommended. Something available in 375 is important because I'm practicing mostly on my own and vermouth doesn't last long. Oddly, I recently saw a niche mention of Cinzano bianco as a cheapo sub (but less sweet) for Lillet Blanc and Cocchi Americano, so I'm getting that next. I'll take more time to taste the Dolin neat in the next couple days before I decide if I want to explore vermouths more on their own in the near future.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So I've got several suggestions for OP.
A. Increase the density of another kind of legume by using it as a flour. Chickpea flour is very, very cheap and the protien content is double that of wheat flour. Many of the more exotic bean flours rate even higher.
>Lupin beans can be ground into a flour, and this is widely used in parts of Europe and in Australia as an additive to wheat flour, enhancing the flavour and lending a rich, creamy colour to the resulting foods
There you go, try to buy it debittered as a flour. If it's not debittered it's poisonous however.
B. Find other cheap protien sources, as vegetable protien usually has an incomplete amino acid profile you should eat a wide variety of vegetable proteins anyway, don't just take the one with the highest nominal protein content.
C. In Ecuador, the lupin is often consumed as a ceviche-like street food known as "cevichochos".
So you can brine them yourself and make a range of salads.

Where do you live btw, it helps to know what's available ingredients wise

If you've got digestive issues use dry beans, change the water several times, don't cook the shit out of them.

I think these lupin beans aren't a staple food, they're like an antipasta. You could put them in a lot of things like you would with olives, but trying to eat a lot will cause you grief.
North Africans eat them just as a beer snack.

Of these, MS Pot Roast and Kielbasa are the quickest. Ofc you can reduce the types of chopped vegs in the others to shave off prep time or buy in smaller pieces (small pots., baby carrots, pre-minced garlic, chopped onions).
Pot Roast : chopped onions, potatos, carrots, celery, garlic, preferred seasonings; add 2-4 lb. roast, 1 cup beef broth or red wine; 10 hours on low, 6 on high
Mississippi Pot Roast (even simpler) : add 3-4 lb. roast; jar of pepperocinis on top including juice; set stick of butter on top; on top pour 1 packet each of au jus, ranch mix; 10 hours on low
Beef Stew : same as Pot Roast, but use chopped stew meat, add 1 Tblsp. worcestershire sauce; 8 hours on low, 5 hours on high
Kielbasa & Sauerkraut : about 28 oz sauerkraut; large kielbasa ring on top, pour 12 oz bottle dark lager or brown ale such as Munich Dunkel or Vienna Lager; 8 hours on low, 4 on high

posts.com: NY strip, ribeye, flat iron, or something else?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: ny strip is the universally agreed the best grilling steak

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: For grilling I like ribeye. I don't grill often and the marbling of ribeye makes it more forgiving if I over cook it a little. Otherwise i prefer ny strip since I usually reverse sear

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Flank or hangar are really good grilled, but do tend to be pricy, so NY strip is my usual go-to just for cost alone.

Also, if you're cooking flank or hangar, I would hope you're cooking for a group. Great centerpiece for a dinner on the deck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18824291
I was under the impression that ribeye is the most popular cut or at least the favorite at steakhouses
>>18824313
Are those usually thinner cuts? Or are the images deceiving and it’s just a really large cut? I prefer a thick steak so I can get a hard crust and keep the inside more rare

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18824334
3inch thick bone in ribeye, so you can smoke it some a grill it. Think reverse sear, but on the grill.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18824334
Yeah, flanks and hangars are thinner, but they are quite long. Sometimes up to 2ft long if you find a really good one.

I usually will make a simple marinade and let sit for 1 hour, sear them super hard and fast to get grill marks on both sides, and often that's all it'll take for them to get to rare. Rest for 5, then slice up the whole length into strips for your guests to pick at.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18824366
That does sound lovely, thanks for the tip

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18824278
I think flank steak. Anything on the cow thats fatty and worked but has enough separation of fibers that its not like chewing leather is good for grilling. For pan frys and reverse sears i like tender meat with good marbling since a lot of the flavor has to be imparted on the steak during the cooking process so something like a ribeye or a filet mignon. Lately i have soured on filets though because they dont really taste like anything and they dont have any fat. Tri tip is another nice grilling steak, cheap and full of fat and you get a nice spectrum where one side is thick and the other is thin so you can keep one side on the hot spot of the grill and cook the other side on a more mild spot and it wont be as uneven as a ribeye for example. tri tips also marinate really nice, i like doing stuff like pineapple pulp or newmans salad dressing. Thanks for reading my blogpost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18824366
>>18824446
Hangar steak is really excellent as steak tartare, so you don't even really need to worry about cooking it to any extent. Just get a nice sear on it without burning or overcooking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: They’re all good on charcoal. Get it up to 500-550 and either seat and put to the indirect side or put to indirect side and reverse sear. Doesn’t matter what cut tri tip ny strip skirt flank fuckin hamburger it’s all delicious

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18822108
>So supposedly bread and pasta etc are no good, they're filled with onions and sugar and trans fats
Only bad bread and bad pasta. Normal bread if you are in europe contains normal ingredients. If you get it in the supermarket, assume some agent to make it last longer as well as slightly more sugar to feed the yeast. If you get it in the US, same story, except a bit more in terms of additives for cultural reasons.
Pasta will be largely fine, it's mostly semolina and optionally egg.
They are still not the healthiest, because they they contain simple carbs, but other than the fact that they are carbs, pasta and bread are fine. Try to get bread at a bakery. One that actually bakes, not one that just puts premade buns in the oven without making the dough themselves, because those mixes have additives.
>If I buy flour from the supermarket, is it secretly filled with hundreds of gay chemicals just like the bread?
Not really, it'll just be plain flour. The only chemicals that you don't want that could be in there will be pesticides and insecticides as well as possibly certain fertilizers.
If you want to avoid those, look into "organic" certifications. In germany for example there's "bio" labels, most of which guarantee no use of chemical insecticides and pesticides as well as no use of chemical fertilizer (usually with the one exception of normal nitrogen based fertilizer, which is also fine, so no issues there).
So get organic flour, but makes sure it actually has some sort of certification and read on that certifications website if that certification is enough for your expectations.
You are probably being schizo about these topics, but I'm not here to tell you what to care about, that's your decision. This is just how you'd get the result you want.

>>18822108
Look at the ingredients. Most pastas contain literally nothing but wheat and some vitamins they add. Shitty wonderbread-tier breads contain a bunch of soy ingredients, but you are talking 1 gram of less per serving. Who gives a shit if you eat a sandwich a day?

I live in Houston. One of the worst metro areas in the entire world. It's literally known as the endless suburbs. We have no zoning rules here, which means in downtown Houston there are strip clubs near churches in the shadow of skyscrapers with taco trucks and halal meats trucks lining both sides of the street from 10am to 10pm until they're forced to drive to the bar scene.
If you don't live downtown you live in a suburb. Not in a house, mind you, but the area itself is effectively a suburb.
It sprawls outward and outward and outward, endlessly in every direction. Houston is a fucking parasite on the surrounding land and within 50 years if left unchecked and assuming a hurricane doesn't permanently flood it, Houston will be the largest city by landmass in the world.

I can walk for 6 minutes with my girlfriend, or 4 minutes by myself, and reach 3 grocery stores, a liquor store, gas stations, multiple coffee shops, multiple fast food, an italian restaurant, vietnamese, thai buffet, 2 indian restaurants, sushi bar, boba tea shop, multiple gyms, multiple all-night bodegas, a head shop, a hookah bar, multiple strip clubs, multiple churches, a public pool, a park, a dogpark, bicycle trail, jogging path, a mosque, a temple, wherever Sikhs go to worship, Metro bus routes, a cell phone store, and Shipleys (a donut shop). The furthest thing from us is the boba tea shop, which is 8 minutes walking with her.

Used to take us 10 minutes together but I made her develop some stamina and take the stairs instead of elevator.
Houston is also known for having some of the worst public transportation in the US.
So, instead of blaming the city for public transportation or homeless encampments or for a lack of walkability, blame them and the state for zoning laws. Zoning laws are the least free thing ever. Telling people what they can or can't do with their own property based on arbitrary lines drawn on a map by politicians? Kek.

Adding a second story to the garage and renting it out? Zoning laws.
Altering your basement? Zoning laws.
Below ground pool? Zoning laws.
Start a small store or open an amateur kitchen? Zoning laws.

And these aren't things you can simply get a permit for and be allowed to do in most cities, thanks to zoning laws.

>>18819726
Right after the unification of Italy a guy called Pellegrino Artusi travelled the country and wrote the first Italian cookbook. It's from 1891, not even 150 years ago.

He's the first to describe a ragu (from French ragout) in the fashion of Bologna. He advises against using tomatoes, "as they stick their nose into everything they shouldn't, just like priests do" (they were a huge fad at the time). But he does allow milk and fresh porcini.

Bolognese sauce only became popular in the 1960s and only in the US, and by that time it had become unrecognizable (poor illiterate migrants like Marcella Hazan and war vets didnn't know how to cook).

I make Bolognese with beef and pork, many herbs, no milk, i finish it in the oven.

My mirepoix is 2:1:1 onion carrot celery, modern carrot is far too sweet. Half my onion is brown, half is like shalotte.
And i really cook my mirepoix, like it has to be transparent onions and beginning to caramelize.

I use olive oil and if by mince had too much fat i actually pour it into a bowl, brown my meat properly then add the bowl back in.

Fresh sauce tomatoes > natural bottle tomato > acid added tin tomato > tomato paste > salad tomato.
Salad tomato is a shit i shake my dick at.
If my tomatoes are like some acid shit rather than using milk I'll use a bit of soda, now that idea might make some people angry but i only do this when i have to and only because adding milk is a shit i shake my dick at.

Every family does it different, if you find another family you better tell me because we probably got a beef with them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Before you assholes make fun of the Campbell's soup, look at the ingredients. It's goddamn tomato paste with addons.

1 Cast Iron Ceramic pot, small
2 Cups ground beef
3/4 Cup Onion fine dice
1/2 Cup Celery fine dice
1/2 Cup Carrot fine dice
1/2 tbsp oregano
1/2 tbsp basil
1/2 tsp garlic powder.
1 tsp rosemary
2 tbsp butter
1 tsp red wine vinegar
1 tsp red pepper flakes
1 tsp fresh ground 4 pepper blend
2 Cans Whole Tomato
1 Can Campbell's tomato soup.
1 Can Mushroom slices

Over medium high heat brown ground beef in cast iron pot and reserve. Add butter and onion, working the fond off the pan into the onion.
Brown onion then add carrot and celery and mix. Sweat mixture unti soft. Blitz one can of tomato to sauce consistency and add to pot, bring to a
boil and reduce heat accordingly, cleaning bottom of the pot with spatula. Cut second can of tomato into bit sized pieces and add. add spices and vinegar.
stir and bring to a strong simmer and cook for about 45 minutes. Simmer until a thick sauce consistency with a sweet flavour developing in the tomato.
Add soup, mushroom and ground beef and stir until thoroughly mixed. Spatula darkening sauce from the sides of pot and mix in.
Cook for another 30 minutes.

>>18819573
Grate the carrots and celery (discard strands).
Use a mixture of available meats consisting of beef, pork veal, and some sausage (mild or hot).
Cook all moisture out of the veggies and meat until you hear a crackling sound and the meat gets a bit crusty.
When you are done adding the tomatoes and other liquids, bake it uncovered for 2-3 hours occasionally removing the grease that comes to the top and then stirring.
This will carnalize the tomatoes and concentrate the mixture by reducing the liquid.

(the pot cleans up easily)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
heres a recipe I made for a friend for my lasagna.

I never used a written recipe and learned from watching someone else make it. They never used a written recipe either.

all amounts were pulled out of my ass based on a best guess for the recipe. because the amounts of many of the seasonings don't matter that much. The person I gave it to said it was the best lasagna they had ever had. they had no trouble making it and never questioned me on exact measurements.

2 lbs. sweet and/or hot Italian sausage
1 package Lasagna Noodles
1 Table spoon olive oil
2 16oz. cans diced or crushed stewed tomatoes
2 or 3 lbs. Mozzarella cheese
Italian seasoning
dried chopped parsley
2 or 3 pints ricotta cheese
2 or 3 eggs
1 white onion medium to large
6 to 8 medium size mushrooms
2 or 3 cloves fresh garlic

Mix the 2 or 3 eggs, 2 or 3 tablespoons parsley, and Ricotta cheese together.

Chop the Mushrooms.

Boil the noodles in a large saucepan with the oil, and 1 tsp. salt in the water,
cook until still tough. drain and refill pan with cold water to keep noodles from
sticking together.

Coarse chop the onion, smash and finely dice 1 or 2 cloves of garlic.
Remove the sausage casing, and break up the sausage in a frying pan.
Brown the sausage with 2/3 the onion and all the garlic, salt and pepper to taste.
Drain off the grease.

In a 2 quart sauce pan combine the Stewed tomatoes, 1 tsp. Italian seasoning, the rest of the onion, 1 crushed and finely chopped clove of garlic, the mushrooms, and the Sausage.
bring to boil and then simmer about 15 minutes.

Arrange in layers in a ungreased 9x13" pan: sauce, ricotta cheese, mozzarella, and pasta.
Top the last layer with a generous amount of mozzarella.
Bake at 350 for 20 to 25 minutes or until sauce bubbles and the cheese is slightly brown.
