secret ingredient to try for thickness is chickpea powder...will thicken up the wateryness, since you are using canned peas.
No no no on the peanut butter. Source out some tahini.
Zero need for yogurt in the actual hummus. Feel free to make some yogurt on the side lebneh, but not blended into the hummus.\
It's fine to skip the cumin, but you might enjoy getting your hands on some dried spice called za'atar. Rub some olive oil on a flat bread, with za'atar, and toast a moment. The sesame seeds in the spice blend and all those green herbs really goes nicely with a fresh batch of hummus.
Sneak in a little lemon zest with your lemon juice in the blender too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18823937
>>1 can of drained chickpeas (approx. 200g)
>>25 grams peanut butter
>>100 grams full fat greek yogurt
>>2 cloves of garlic
Extremely badly
My gran was Lebanese. Her hummus bil-tahina (and, really, that of literally every single woman at her church and all other Leb grammas' hummus, too) was simple: hand mashed chickpeas pressed through mesh to remove the skins, whipped with mashed or grated garlic (she used to mash it, but in her old age, found that using a pestle hurt her wrists so she started using a microplane), olive oil, sesame paste, lemon juice and finely chopped parsley (both sweet and bitter varieties) then salted to taste and drizzled with extra olive oil and dusted with sumac and/or za'atar.
I can understand using PB in place of sesame paste since that's not really a staple ingredient in most non-Levantine homes but the omission of olive oil and use of yoghurt in making it gives me pause. But hey, if you like it, you do you, boo.

To be clear, when I say "hand mash" the chickpeas, I mean that she pinched and mushed up each chickpea individually them pressed the resulting goop through a mesh sieve. Why do people wait so long for sauerkraut when kimchi only takes like 1 week at room temp? Are the ingredients that different that fermentation is slower or something?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18821017
Kraut goes through 3 seperate fermentations by different bacterial colonies. This takes 3 weeks, and produces the most bacterially diverse and complex tasting kraut.

Basically what happens is as one colony metabolizes the primary food in the kraut it starves itself and another colony comes in to consume the previous bacteria's metabolites.

Sort of like how yeast makes sugar into alcohol and when all the sugar runs out acetobacter will come in and turn the alcohol into vinegar.

Bro you need to wait till plantains look rotten before you eat them. Even a little mold on the skin isn’t necessarily a sign they’re too far gone. Once they hit that point, peel them, slice them horizontally, and coat with brown sugar. Heat skillet with butter at high medium. Fry plantains, checking now and then. During frying process, put a couple splashes of gran marnier in skillet. Move plantains around in the juice. Once plantains are done, make a sauce with remaining juice adding more butter/brown sugar/gran marnier as needed. Just make sugar to not make the sauce too thick and caramely.

>Where do I start bros?
Cooking is a bad hobby if you are depressed because you are forced to eat for sustenance. You will put pressure on yourself to cook a lot, and you wont always be able to do so. You will have to eat generic meals and will feel guilty about it, when you are tired and dont want to cook it will eat you up inside. Its a negative feedback loop.

You want to keep your mind busy, make yourself some healthy meals, but start a new hobby altogether to take up your time. If you can cook, you can build something with your hands.

I welcome you to the friendliest and most helpful board (most of the time) on the site.
>>>/diy/

make soup.
>roast chicken
>separate bones and meat
>pressure cook bones with some vinegar
>take that stock and add it to pot
>add the trinity of carrots, celery, and onion. fry them beforehand if desired
from there add pretty much whatever you want, and add the chicken meat back in at the end. today I'm doing cabbage, peas, and beans in addition to the above, and of course various spices, herbs, and bouillon. also using some turkey bones I saved from turkey I bought for cheap and smoked after thanksgiving, and the drippings from some pulled pork I made, kind of like additional stock. interested to see how that turns out

Poor OP.. take it in shifts, ok? Don't grocery shop on the same day as your food prep and cooking endeavors, prolly be too exhausted. Pace yourself to buy something to toss into the microwave, crock pot, or oven for convenience on Day 1. I suggest a pork roast into the oven for carnitas, or some simple rubbed chicken parts, or a big flank steak to broil. Should last a couple of meals, and give you time for simple prep to top a salad or make a wrap on Day 2.
